description:
Catagonus wagneri, commonly known as the Chacoan peccary or Tagua, is a species of peccary native to the Gran Chaco region of South America. It is one of the rarest and most endangered peccary species in the world.

Catagonus wagneri is a medium-sized, hoofed mammal that belongs to the family Tayassuidae. It has a stocky build, a rounded snout, and a short, coarse coat that ranges in color from grayish-brown to blackish-brown. The Chacoan peccary is known for its distinctive facial markings, including a white stripe on the snout and a dark band around the eyes.

This species is well-adapted to the hot and dry environment of the Gran Chaco, with a specialized digestive system that allows it to consume a wide variety of plant material, including tough, fibrous vegetation. Chacoan peccaries typically live in small groups and exhibit complex social behaviors, such as vocalizations and scent-marking.

Catagonus wagneri is classified as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species, primarily due to habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as hunting pressure. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique and ecologically important species.
